Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Story: I could feel my phone buzzing in my pocket as I finished rinsing the dye from my client’s hair. My heart clenched; I knew it was probably another message from my boyfriend. He’d lost his brother just two days ago, and every part of me wanted to be by his side, holding him, listening, just being there. But right now, I was at the salon, and my client—a first-time visitor—was staring at her reflection, her lips pressed tight in disappointment. She hesitated, then quietly said, “It’s a bit warmer than I expected.” I could see the hope in her eyes that I’d fix it, that I’d make her feel beautiful. My mind raced, torn between the urge to rush to my boyfriend, to be the comfort he needed, and the professional responsibility to reassure my client, to address her concerns with patience and care. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I stood there, hands trembling, caught between two worlds that needed me in completely different ways.
